name: Choas Theory rushing big breakers
description:
Chaos theory rushing to bring out big guns. Basic combo is Test Run + Scavenge/Eureka but if you happen to draw big breakers first, you can discard them and Retrieval Run it. Infiltration and Tinkering will help you apply early game pressure or help you choose which one to bring out first. Same old thing is such an essential card in this deck. It increases consistency of this deck by miles.

I have a problem though. I couldn't find the room for the Plascrete Carapace. Any idea on what to cut? Initially, I build this on Kit but it is painfully long to set up and start going so, I switched it to Chaos Theory.

Suggestion/ comments?

name: Toolkit
description:
Goals: -Tutor out breakers with either SMC if mid-run or with Test Run + Scavenge as prep for big runs. Most likely to install Yog.0 on the Dinosaurus early on due to Kit's ability, switch to either Morning Star or Garrote as necessary depending on game state. -Exploit Replicator's ability to thin out the deck for more important cards, ie. Tinkering, primary economy cards, Levy AR Lab Access when running out of gas in late game. Install Dyson Mem Chips in order to get 6 MU + Dino to install all three breakers + 2 Datasuckers.

Concerns: -No attack on corp economy aside from forcing rezzing ICE. Long games naturally benefit the runner due to corp draw + decking out, though. Levy makes sure I don't stall on economy. -Program destruction very strong. However, limited ICE with trash program subroutines, at this point makes that a threat. Concerns also include facechecking ICE and losing programs from grip due to net damage.

As this is my first major attempt at deckbuilding, please feel free to give me feedback! Every explanation helps. :)

name: It's a bit elaborate for a toothpick
description: You can put in Imp or Decoy depending on your environment.... I whack these in interchangeably depending on the day. If you want two Decoy then drop one Scavange and one R&D Interface. If you just want one Imp drop one of the above

name: Everything is Yoggable
description: For me Professional Contacts are too slow, so I used John Masanori instead. That made the place for singleton Inside Job to surprise the corp.

name: Zer0 Monolith Rush v.2
description:
Changes:

-1 R&D interface +1Dyson -1 Magnum Opus +1Deux Ex -1 Cyber cypher +1Gordian Blade -2 Modded +1 Sahasrara +1Sacrificial Construct

Inspiration for: + Big Girls Play With Monoliths (PeekaySK)

name: NBN: Accelerated Power Shutdown
description:
NBN fast advance that uses Restructure to get big money. Don't rez ice your first turn to (hopefully) get above the Restructure point, then its smooth sailing.

From 4 points you can do the Accelerated Diagnostic -> Power Shutdown combo to snag the win.

name: NBN: Money is Power (Shutdown)
description:
All the Money, All the Time. Get lots of money, use it to rez San Sans behind Tollbooths and fast advance your agendas.

The Power Shutdowns are there to kill Datasuckers

name: NBN: Financial Capital of the World
description:
Nothing subtle here... use the economy operations to get a big bank, rez a SanSan, and score agendas.

If you can land an early Snoop trace, don't forget that its instant unpreventable net damage. Just in case someone face plants a Neural Katana with 3 cards :)

name: NBN-NILIF: Nothing in Life Is Free
description:
My first deck is a deeply experimental one (I think) with emphasis on taxing the runner for whatever they do. Lots of access-triggered ice, and other runner action-triggered cards.

Economy is unconventional and potentially weak. Credits come largely from Sweeps Week and Profiteering (with tag removal by Veterans) and virtual income provided by Shipment from SanSan. Most cards are low cost to balance small income.

Ice count low too because keeping runner out isn't the point; letting them in and making them wish they hadn't is. Larger than usual selection of Upgrades does the work in place of ice.

Scoring comes via basic Fast Advance setup.

Tagging is primarily for Resource trashing, but pair of Closed Accounts provide enough threat to inspire clearing and fear.

If this is proven wrongheaded approach or there are better cards for my intended function, I'd love to hear feedback.

name: Public Protest 1.1
description:
An improved version of a deck I put up a few weeks ago. For those who missed it, the deck is tag-me style, save that it runs loads of cheap, powerful resources. It's main goal is to keep the corp poor by making it rez ice at extra cost (ID, and Rook) while force it to trash a varity of resources.

E.g. the corp is basically forced to trash data leak the turn after its played, I haven't had the thing stick around and not won the game shortly their after.

Some changes I made:

I cut account siphon for another vamp to free up influence. The main goal of the vamp/account siphon was to make the corp poor and the extra credits weren't really necessary. The deck is very cheap.

Add some emergency shut downs because... this should be obvious.

added 3 gorman drips v1. I just want to say these things have been INSANE. They regularly gain me 9 credits, and its not like the corp is often in a position where it can take a turn just purging them and not gaining money. This goes for all the other viruses. They force the corp to spend actions not gaining money and further causing them poverty.

1 paricia: trying it out to see if it works to help fight asset based economies.

name: Weyland Toast
description:
Primary win condidtion is flatline by either couple of Punitive Counterstrike or Scorched.

With careful runner you should have no problem advancing two of your six fatties behind well advanced Hadrian or Ice Wall. Commercialization allows you to capitalize on your wall in the meantime.

Tested on today's tournament in my homecity. Fared extremely well - three times won in 4-5 turns by flatlining the runner with Counterstrike. Only once through agenda victory - the last runner was very careful.

name: The Locksmith
description:
An experiment trying to utilize Keyhole in a Kit deck. Using Keyhole, Kit can trash economy cards and ICE making fighting off Yog.0 on Dinosaurus incredibly difficult. Keyhole together with Datasucker also work to force Corps to ICE Archives, spreading their resources further. Doing all of this while trying to score Agendas may really stretch the Corp thin. With these strategies combined, R&D may be weaken to the point to allow multiple Keyhole runs, which makes for peeking on 3 new cards every run.

Issues with the deck are the 1x copies of Icebreakers, Memory, and performance greatly affected by how the early game goes. If you can manage to get Keyhole going early enough, the Corp will always be playing catch up however getting it late can make it almost a non-issue. Intelligent running and a bit of luck can get you a long way with a Yog.0, so Crypsis shouldn't need to be used too much, and Sharpshooter/Deus X can help in a pinch against the scary ICE you can't seem to trick your way past.

name: Next Level 3.0
description: Includes lots of cheap ice to support NEXT Design and Accelerated Beta Test. Click intensive economy with Efficiency Committee, Gila, & Melange.

name: Chaos Theories 4.0
description: CT with no console, just her built in memory. Lightweight rig with recurring one-shot options.

name: Weyland Toast
description: Replaced a trap nobody was getting into with SEA Source
